content:
To add, it's important to see that when you think it's appropriate to do something for some theoretical reason you try to pursue it for "some reason", but also to see that when you would like to do something genuinely it is without reason entirely. 

There is a difference between "I want to go and do this" vs. "I want to go to medical school because then my parents will stop criticizing me and it's a good compromise between engineering which I hate and being a lawyer". Is there an action because of "some reason" or an action for no reason other than direct intention.
lol, it's more important to realize that the idea is that it's really important to mold and shape reality to your will is the same as asking why your will demands the changes.

If you don't feel like self-inquiry would be appropriate then pursue the things that you thing would be helpful its not meant to be a prescription or necessity. 

Not trying to be difficult, but the idea of "why even do *this thing* if there is no point??" is caused by the belief there is *something* you think you were supposed to get or experience. 

I encourage you to pursue anything you're interested in, but keep in mind if you do anything practical like making xyz money, achieving a career goal, philosophically understanding, getting a degree, dating someone, etc. That you might think "that is what I want", but once you achieve it you are then like "eh, yeah got it now, so anyway". This is the progression of self-realization in that it is procedurally "getting what you want" but it not being fulfilling entirely. The root being our actual "self" we want to understand and realize. 

I'm suggesting that that when we say "do I want external achievement or internal understanding?" it is actually the same thing. The objective is simply "doing what I think is intelligent", and then to observe how that changes over time.

My point of view is that free will doesn't exist in that it literally doesn't exist and is a moot question. Like dividing by 0. It requires an actor who could have done multiple things but only did one, which does not exist. Any actor or physical being only does or "did" one thing and all actions are linear. The basis of this is not mathematical, and I'd be open to conflicting perspective in that regard, but subjectively it is clear that we do not experience "multiple choice", we only experience a linear experience of "this thought, then this thought, then this thought" and linear action. 

Emotions are generated by the brain/nervous system in response to our senses. It is an important part of observation/self-inquiry to realize that emotions are not "I experience a thing over there", but that emotions and our senses are part of "Me" as it prevails. 

From my perspective, all emotions related to thinking (except for very, very particular circumstances) end, but emotions related to immediate sensory experience continue. Conventionally we experience emotions related to our immediate sensory perception and also our relationship to what we *think is happening to me* it is this emotional pathway that completely ends. 

I will emphasize again, because it is not a natural or encouraged way to look at things, but you exist. If you slap yourself in the face and say "what the fuck is actually going on, why *do* I exist?" this is the place that inquiry starts. Not that there is a secret answer, but that the question must arise.

Using the metaphor it is reverting to being plant-like with capacities and intelligence of a human. Instead of constantly emotionally responding to whatever you believe is happening in your imagination, in the same way we emotionally respond to all the imagined things in a dream that aren't real, you automatically accept and respond to exactly what is physically occurring all the time with no objection and there is no imagined past, future, or ideal. We are social creatures like a dog, so we care about that stuff, but that's included when I'm saying you have the capacities and interests of a human, but subjectively you experience it all like a plant. 

A more comforting analogy is that most animals live below the clouds because they can't think with complexity. Most people suffer emotionally because they are stuck in the clouds, and metaphorically, self-realization is not going below the clouds, but going above them, so you have all the capacity of human, but none of the suffering associated with the complexity of thought that erroneously invents a self-concept, mistakes it for ourselves, and then becomes indentured and trapped by it. There is no "higher function" in anyway, but there is an abscence of the negative experience that was previously self-invented.

You're overthinking. It's just a simple distinction to help people begin to analyze their subjective experience. 

If I say "colours are a property of sight" we all get this. It's very basic and simple. If I say "a loud noise is a property of hearing" we all get this. If I say "you touch something with your hand you will feel a texture, if you hit it really hard you will feel pain" we all get this. Emotions are the same way in that they are just a sensation we separate from our senses that are instead a response to them that are internally generated. it's not a precise definition we just all instinctually know what they are. 

The only thing I am trying to avoid is that a lot of people who really haven't observed this or try to intellectually overcomplicate are like "so, the colour red... you say it is a property of sight, but I associate it with anger, violence, and physicality? Is it just a sense, or an emotion? Or is it something that embodies an entire cultural value all at once?" . What I am saying is shut the fuck up, red is a colour. You see it with your eyes. We are going back to basics and then before that, not using lofty clever interpretations to reconfigure our actual experience, it's the other direction. 

Even with that said, self-image causes us to be completely out of touch and intellectualize our emotions, but nevertheless they are still intuitive, we all know what they are, it's just important that at a base level we are aware that when we are talking about emotions, we don't mean *pain* we don't mean memory, we mean the literal and exact sensations in our body and brain that we call *emotions*. 

All of this occurs under the umbrella of "awareness" or subjective experience, they are just automatically perceived as separate phenomena.

I don't see resolution to the question of individuation. If you look at 100 people and say "they all have consciousness because their biology has developed the faculty through physical evolution" this is not a problem, I agree with this and see it as objectively a valid observation. What is not resolvable in my view is the statement "Yes, I agree, but why I am in this one?".

That's a fair point. What I mean is to just draw a distinction between what is sensory/physical sensation is and what is emotional. An example is that pain is physical, hunger is physical, and our sensory perceptions are physical. They are all in some way related to an actual event that is taking place physically that causes a response by the body. I'm probably wording this a bit sloppily, but just think of a plant vs. a dog vs. a human. With plant, absolutely everything is physical. If you put it in the right physical conditions, it will grow well and if you don't it suffers. If you take a dog, it is sort of like that in many ways, but also if you treat it poorly from a social perspective, the dog will be dislike you, be unhappy, sad etc. With a human, they have the additional layer of being capable of literally inventing a fantasy of how their life should be, and feeling emotionally distressed if they are not experiencing that imaginary state, which most animals, even intelligent ones, are not sufficiently capable of experiencing. 

Self-realization to some degree is akin to being a perfectly normal human with all of our capacities, but a reversion to the natural state of being "plant-like" in that everything you do is just a physical response to your environment and nature.

2. What do you mean when you say ‚Äúconsciousness‚Äù and ‚Äúawareness of sensory experience‚Äù are different things

It is often circumstantial how I'd reference it, but "consciousness" usually references the objective characteristic we intuit as "yeah, other people are "conscious"" and cows are "conscious", whereas dandelions are probably not. That is the objective characteristic of awareness and executive control of the body.

Awareness of sensory experience is the subjective awareness you are currently experiencing as "Me".

It's not really a scientific mystery that there is probably many individually conscious intelligent creatures on planet earth. All of us humans sort of assume each other is conscious and we assume that intelligent mammals are also conscious. What is not resolvable as far as I've been able to understand is why "I" am experiencing my own individual subjective awareness. This used to be referred to as the "soul" but it is really just "yeah, objectively I get that consciousness may be produced by the intelligent brain, but why do I exist inside this one?" The recognition of *what I actually am* that I call "Me" is the awareness of sensory experience.

3. What is your definition of emotion and how can crying at non-physical stimuli not be caused by emotion?

Crying is a form of communication it isn't an emotion. It occurs in conjunction with an emotion for most people the same way frustration and anger are the same thing for most people but they are completely different. Anger is an emotion that is caused by the perception you or another has been wronged by another unintelligently, but frustration is a lack of communication between you and another person. If there is an active self-image, these are basically the same thing, but if there isn't, they are basically never connected. 

When I cry now it is 99% of the time related to someone else experiencing joy or happy novelty, like when people wear those 
colour blind glasses and are really happy. Same thing when someone struggles and then succeeds, etc. I don't feel sad, I don't feel anything, but I cry because it is an expression of "oh, that is a really good thing that we should be encouraging in our society". It is very similar to laughter at something that is funny. I don't feel happy when I laugh, I am already happy, it is an automatic expression of "oh, that is an intelligent expression of novelty for our culture/common ideas".

"I logically understand that the signal cannot be thought about. Any thought of the signal is no longer the signal. But I‚Äôm having trouble shaking my identification with it. Any tips or advice?"

You don't shake identification with anything and there is no objective to do so, just look at what you do think you are and see if there are inconsistencies or faults in that. The error correction leads you to lack of identification.

"also jamie are you defining emotions as senses? "

No. Emotions aren't a sensory experience. They are very specific from my point of view but from a what we all experience, our emotions are internally generated while sensory experiences are externally generated. Seeing is sensory, hearing is sensory, pain is sensory. Sadness is internal, love is internal, shame is internal, fear is internal. There is no need for external stimulus for those to occur.
